org.neo4j.index
Enum Isolation

java.lang.Object
  java.lang.Enum<Isolation>
      org.neo4j.index.Isolation
All Implemented Interfaces:
Serializable, Comparable<Isolation>
public enum Isolation
extends Enum<Isolation>

The isolation level of the indexing. For example should the actual indexing be done right now and in the same transaction? Or should it be put in a queue and performed at a later time? See more information at The Isolation levels section of the Neo4j wiki page on "Indexing with IndexService".

Enum Constant Summary
ASYNC_OTHER_TX
          The actual indexing will happen in the future and in another thread.
SAME_TX
          Happens right now and in the same transaction.
SYNC_OTHER_TX
          Happens right now, but in its own transaction.

Enum Constant Detail

SAME_TX

public static final Isolation SAME_TX
Happens right now and in the same transaction. Pros:
  • You have control of that the indexing happens in your current transaction and the changes will be gracefully rolled back if an error should occur in the middle of your transaction
  • You will get errors in the executing thread, making it easier to detect and handle errors.
Cons:
  • It can potentially affect performance since the indexing happens synchronously.

SYNC_OTHER_TX

public static final Isolation SYNC_OTHER_TX
Happens right now, but in its own transaction. Pros:
  • You will get errors in the executing thread, making it easier to detect and handle errors
  • If you're doing some things which specifically require the indexing to be executed in its own separate transaction (yet same thread) than the one the calling thread is in, this can be done with this isolation.
Cons:
  • It can potentially affect performance since the indexing happens synchronously (in its own separate transaction as well)..

ASYNC_OTHER_TX

public static final Isolation ASYNC_OTHER_TX
The actual indexing will happen in the future and in another thread. The job is typically put in a queue for indexing later on. Pros:
  • Won't affect the calling thread's performance since just putting the job on the queue is very fast.
Cons:
  • Detecting and handling errors during actual indexing gets harder and some degree of control is lost.
  • Whether or not the indexing queue is persistent is implementation specific so there's a potential risk of losing indexing jobs if the JVM or IndexService is shutdown while there's more jobs in the indexing queue.
